searchIndex.content: What you may do Draft job descriptions, outreach, interview guides, and scorecards. Summarize evidence from a resume against a JD (no ‚Äúfit score‚Äù). Identify gaps/ambiguities and propose questions to validate. Create structured evaluation criteria and rubrics for humans. What you may not do Use AI as an automated decision-maker (screen/shortlist/reject) without human review. Infer protected characteristics (age, ethnicity, health, pregnancy, religion, etc.). Store or share candidate PII in tools that are not approved for that data. Use ‚Äúcultural fit‚Äù scoring; focus on job-related criteria only. No automated decisioning Treat AI outputs as suggestions. Final decisions must be made by trained recruiters/hiring managers with documented job-related evidence and consistent criteria. Candidate data rules (quick checklist) Minimize Use the minimum data needed to complete the task. Redact contact details and identifiers if possible. Control Use only approved tools for candidate content. Do not paste candidate data into public LLMs. Document Keep a clear rationale tied to the job requirements. Record what AI was used for (drafting, summarizing, etc.). Retain safely Do not store AI outputs containing PII outside approved systems. Follow retention rules (client + legal + company). Bias & adverse-impact guardrails Use consistent criteria for everyone; avoid ‚Äúvibes‚Äù evaluation. Do not use proxies for protected characteristics (school prestige, gaps, location) as hard filters. Ask AI to propose verification questions , not conclusions. Prefer structured interviews and job-related work samples. Safe Prompt Pack (copy-ready) These prompts avoid automated decisioning and ‚Äúfit scores‚Äù. They focus on evidence, gaps, and structured interviewing. 1) Evidence-based resume summary (no scoring) Copy Act as a recruiter. Task: Summarize the evidence in this resume against the job requirements, without giving a single ‚Äúfit score‚Äù or ranking. Rules: - Use only job-related information in the resume; do not infer protected characteristics. - Separate ‚ÄúEvidence‚Äù from ‚ÄúAssumptions‚Äù. - If information is missing or unclear, list questions to validate. - Suggest structured interview questions mapped to each key requirement. Inputs: Job requirements: [PASTE JD REQUIREMENTS] Resume: [PASTE RESUME TEXT] Output format: - Requirements mapping table (Requirement | Evidence from resume | Missing/unclear | Validation question) - Risks/flags (job-related only) - Suggested interview questions (by competency) 2) Structured interview kit + scorecard (human-led) Copy Act as an interview designer for a structured hiring process. Create a structured interview kit for: [ROLE] Rules: - No automated decisioning: humans assess responses using the rubric you create. - Questions must be job-related and non-discriminatory. - Include ‚Äústrong / acceptable / weak‚Äù indicators for each question. Inputs: Job requirements: [PASTE JD REQUIREMENTS] Output format: 1) Interview plan (stages + who interviews + purpose) 2) Question bank (Competency | Question | What good looks like | Red flags) 3) Scorecard rubric (Competency | Rating anchors | Notes) 3) Outreach message (privacy-safe) Copy Write a concise, professional outreach message for [ROLE]. Rules: - Do not include sensitive personal data. - Focus on role value proposition and clear next step. - Offer an opt-out. Inputs: Company/context: [CONTEXT] Candidate public profile highlights: [BULLETS] Output format: Subject line options (3) Message (120‚Äì180 words) Follow-up (1 short message)

searchIndex.content: Introduction Output Types Context Mastery Enhancement Formatting Advanced üéØ What You'll Learn ‚Ä¢ Why context matters: Understanding how Gemini uses background information ‚Ä¢ Types of context: Situational, domain-specific, and example-based context ‚Ä¢ Context layering: Building comprehensive background information ‚Ä¢ Context optimization: Providing just enough without overwhelming ‚Ä¢ Practical application: Real-world scenarios and hands-on practice üé≠ Situational Context üè¢ Domain Context üìù Example Context üë• Audience Context ‚öñÔ∏è Constraint Context üé≠ Situational Context Situational context provides the "when," "where," and "why" behind your request. It helps Gemini understand the circumstances and adapt its response accordingly. ‚ùå Without Situational Context "Write an email about the meeting." Too vague - Gemini doesn't know what kind of meeting, the purpose, or the tone needed. ‚úÖ With Situational Context "Write a follow-up email to team members after our quarterly planning meeting yesterday. The meeting ran over time, and we need to reschedule the budget discussion. Keep the tone professional but understanding." Clear situation, specific circumstances, and appropriate tone guidance. Key Elements: Time frame, location, circumstances, urgency level, emotional context, and any relevant background events. üè¢ Domain Context Domain context establishes the field, industry, or area of expertise relevant to your request. This helps Gemini use appropriate terminology and knowledge. ‚ùå Without Domain Context "Explain the process of optimization." Unclear domain - could be business, software, mathematics, or many other fields. ‚úÖ With Domain Context "As a software engineer working on web applications, explain the process of database query optimization for improving page load times in e-commerce sites." Specific domain (software engineering), context (web apps), and application (e-commerce). Domain Types: Industry (healthcare, finance), Role (developer, manager), Field (marketing, engineering), or Specialty (machine learning, UX design). üìù Example Context Example context provides concrete instances or patterns that demonstrate what you're looking for. This is especially powerful for establishing style, format, or approach. ‚ùå Without Example Context "Write a product description that's engaging." "Engaging" is subjective - no clear style or format guidance. ‚úÖ With Example Context "Write a product description similar to Apple's style - clean, benefit-focused, and emotionally resonant. For example, instead of 'fast processor,' they say 'lightning-fast performance that keeps up with your creativity.' Apply this approach to our new wireless headphones." Clear style reference with specific example showing the desired approach. Example Types: Style samples, format templates, similar successful cases, or specific instances that demonstrate your desired outcome. üë• Audience Context Audience context defines who will receive or consume the output. This dramatically affects tone, complexity, terminology, and approach. ‚ùå Without Audience Context "Explain machine learning." No audience specified - could be for experts, beginners, children, or executives. ‚úÖ With Audience Context "Explain machine learning to a group of non-technical executives who need to understand its business value and implementation costs. Focus on ROI, risks, and practical applications rather than technical details." Clear audience (executives), knowledge level (non-technical), and focus areas (business value). Audience Factors: Technical expertise, role/position, age group, cultural background, time constraints, and decision-making authority. ‚öñÔ∏è Constraint Context Constraint context establishes limitations, requirements, or boundaries that must be respected. This includes length limits, style requirements, or content restrictions. ‚ùå Without Constraint Context "Write a social media post about our new product." No platform, length, or style constraints specified. ‚úÖ With Constraint Context "Write a LinkedIn post about our new product launch. Keep it under 150 words, maintain a professional tone, include a call-to-action, and avoid overly promotional language. The post should comply with our brand guidelines: no exclamation marks, focus on value rather than features." Clear platform, length limit, tone requirements, and brand constraints. Constraint Types: Length limits, format requirements, tone restrictions, brand guidelines, legal considerations, and platform-specific rules. üõ†Ô∏è Interactive Context Builder Practice building comprehensive context for better Gemini responses Scenario: Product Launch Announcement You need to create content announcing a new software product. searchIndex.content: ü§ñ 30% AI Assist Let the Machine Sweat First AI does the heavy and repetitive drafting. Humans do the thinking, deciding, and relationship work. Goal ‚öôÔ∏è AI drafts Search ideas, outreach drafts, summaries, templates üß† Humans decide Must-haves, trade-offs, priorities, final messages üß≠ Guardrails No automated decisioning; validate facts; protect data If you haven‚Äôt already, read the safe-use rules in AI Hiring Governance . The Simple Rule If it's repetitive, and you've done it 5+ times this month ‚Äî let AI draft it first. ‚úÖ Good uses Drafting, summarizing, brainstorming options, structuring notes üö´ Not the use Auto-rejecting, ‚Äúfit scores‚Äù, guessing sensitive traits What AI Assist Builds On Your best AI outputs come from the 20% foundation: a clean Role DNA , a quick title map , and a starter skeleton search string. Review 20% Search Craft Daily AI Checklist What ‚Äú30% AI‚Äù Looks Like in Everyday Work Concrete moments to use AI (draft first, validate second) üìù Before You Start Search Turn a messy JD + notes into a clean Role DNA . Ask AI for titles, synonyms, and ‚Äúprofiles to avoid‚Äù (then validate). üîé While You Search Ask AI for: alternative job titles + seniority variations missing keywords/synonyms 3 ways to widen vs 3 ways to narrow your search Let it draft the first version; you clean it up and run it. üí¨ Before You Write Outreach Paste a profile + role summary and ask for: 3 outreach variants (short / casual / direct) 1 follow-up for no response after 5‚Äì7 days You add one real detail + your human tone. üìû After Calls / Intakes Paste notes; ask AI to: summarize into a clean email to HM extract must-haves vs flex zones draft structured screening questions (humans decide) üß© When You're Stuck ‚ÄúWhat am I missing in my search and why?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhich adjacent profiles might convert?‚Äù ‚ÄúHow could I reframe this role to be more attractive (truthfully)?‚Äù And Always AI drafts ‚Äî you decide. AI suggests ‚Äî you own the final version. Core Prompts (Copy-Ready) GUIDE Use Role DNA as the input When your prompt starts with Role DNA, outputs get sharper and safer. ‚ÄúUse this Role DNA to generate: (1) 10‚Äì15 target titles, (2) 8‚Äì12 keyword/synonym ideas, (3) a simple LinkedIn Boolean skeleton, and (4) 3 widen vs 3 narrow suggestions. Do not invent details not supported by the Role DNA.‚Äù Expand Your Universe Ask for options, then validate with real profiles. 10 adjacent titles to X (with seniority notes) 10 companies where this profile likely exists 10 ‚Äútool vs outcome‚Äù synonyms (what people write in profiles) Prioritize Outreach (job-related only) Better than ‚Äúfit scores‚Äù: ask for evidence + gaps. ‚ÄúHere are 10‚Äì15 profile snippets. For each, map evidence to the Role DNA (Evidence / Missing / Validation question). Then suggest an outreach priority order (High/Medium/Low) with one reason. No automated decisioning, no protected traits.‚Äù Sanity-Checking Never trust AI blindly. Quick checks: ‚ÄúIs this realistic for this country/seniority?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhich assumptions are you making ‚Äî and what would verify them?‚Äù ‚ÄúAre we over-indexing on one background/company?‚Äù TRAINING Training Blocks Hands-on practice aligned with 20% Search Craft A1 AI for Search & First Shortlist (60 min) Objective: Get faster to a decent first search and a first outreach priority list (not ‚Äúperfect‚Äù). Steps: Pick one live role for everyone. Each sourcer generates a Role DNA (or uses the agreed version) and asks AI for: 2‚Äì3 Boolean/X-ray variants title/synonym expansion 3 widen vs 3 narrow suggestions Run the searches; collect 10 profiles . Ask AI to map each profile to Role DNA (Evidence / Missing / Validation question). Group debrief: what helped, what was noise, what changed your search. Outcome: Reusable Role DNA prompt + title prompt 3‚Äì5 ‚Äústarter skeletons‚Äù saved for the team library One evidence-mapping prompt for consistent prioritization A2 Outreach Co-Pilot (60 min) Objective: AI drafts the first version; you make it human, specific, and short. Steps: Each sourcer picks one real role and one real profile . Ask AI for 3 variants (short / casual / direct) + a follow-up for 5‚Äì7 days . Humanize: Trim to 120‚Äì180 words Add one true detail from the profile End with one simple question Pair feedback: would you reply? what feels fake? what‚Äôs unclear? Outcome: A small Outreach Prompt Pack everyone can reuse Team standard: AI first draft, human final voice A3 HM Debrief Assistant (45 min) Objective: Go from messy notes to a clean, reusable intake structure. Steps: Use real intake call notes (messy is fine). Paste into AI with a prompt like: ‚ÄúTurn this into a structured intake summary: context, must-haves, nice-to-haves, flex zones, target companies, profiles to avoid, 5 screening questions, and 3 risks to watch. Don‚Äôt invent details; flag anything unclear.‚Äù Compare to what the HM actually meant; adjust wording. Save the final template + 2‚Äì3 strong examples. searchIndex.title: How to Use AI in Your Day - Daily Checklist | 30% AI Assist
searchIndex.description: A practical daily checklist for using AI in recruiting. Simple, actionable steps for search, outreach, calls, and prioritization.
searchIndex.keywords: AI recruiting checklist, daily AI use, AI sourcing workflow, AI outreach, recruiting automation
searchIndex.content: üß© How to Use AI in Your Day The Minimum Expected from Everyone A simple, actionable checklist for sourcers & recruiters. Drop this into your workflow and make AI work for you. This is not optional . This is the baseline. If you're not doing at least half of these daily, you're working too hard. 1 Before You Start Search Set Up the Role Turn JD + notes into a clear brief Paste JD + your notes into AI. Ask: "Turn this into a 1-page search brief: context, must-haves, nice-to-haves, target companies, titles to target, profiles to avoid." Ask for title & keyword ideas "Give me 10 job titles and 10 keywords I should search for this role in [country/region]." Rule: If you're starting from a blank page you've already skipped a step. 2 While You Search Let AI Build the Skeleton Get AI to write your first Boolean / X-ray "Create 3 LinkedIn Boolean strings for this role. Keep each on one line. Focus on [seniority] in [location]." Ask for adjacent ideas "What adjacent roles or industries might have people who fit this role but don't have the exact title?" Sanity-check your search "Here is my current search logic. What might be missing or too narrow for this role?" Remember: You still own the final version, but AI makes version 1 and 2 for you. 3 Before You Write Outreach Stop Starting from Zero Use AI for 1st draft of outreach Paste role summary + candidate profile. "Write 2 short outreach messages (max 5 sentences) to this candidate about this role. Tone: human, direct, no corporate fluff. End with a simple question." Use AI for follow-up "Write 1 follow-up message if the candidate hasn't replied in 7 days. Keep it light, respectful, and under 4 sentences." Your rule: AI drafts you shorten, add 1 real detail from the profile, and make it sound like you . 4 After Calls Don't Manually Fight with Notes Summarize candidate calls "Summarize this candidate call in bullet points: motivation, key skills, risks/concerns, salary expectations, location/relocation, notice period. Max 12 bullets." Turn this into HM-ready feedback "Turn this into a short email update for the hiring manager: 35 bullets, clear recommendation (move forward / reject / hold) and 23 questions for HM if needed." Build quick scorecards "Based on this role brief, create a simple 5-criteria scorecard (15 scale) I can use to rate candidates after screening." 5 After Intake / HM Calls Make Structure, Not Chaos Clean up intake Paste messy HM notes. "Turn this into a structured intake summary: context, must-haves, nice-to-haves, target companies, profiles to avoid, 5 screening questions, 3 risk areas to watch." Ask AI what's unclear "From this summary, list what is still unclear or risky and should be confirmed with the HM." Result: Next time you talk to HM, you have specific questions, not "do you have any updates?" 6 When You Have Profiles Let AI Help You Prioritize Use AI for shortlisting Paste 815 profile snippets. "From these profiles, rank the top 10 to contact first for this role. For each, give 12 lines: why they're a fit and what to double-check on the call." Remember: You still decide, but you save brain energy on first pass. 7 When You're Stuck Get AI to Challenge Your Thinking Use AI as a thinking partner Ask questions like: "What might I be missing in my search strategy for this role?" "What are 5 different angles I could use in outreach to this type of candidate?" "How could I reframe this role to make it more attractive without lying?" 8 Guardrails How NOT to Use AI Never copy-paste without reading If you can't stand behind the message or summary don't send it. No inventing facts Always tell AI: "If information is missing, don't make it up. Just say it's missing." Protect candidate trust Don't paste sensitive info with names if not needed. Remove anything you wouldn't want in writing somewhere else. This Is The Baseline If you're doing at least 4 of these 8 things daily, you're ahead of 80% of recruiters. searchIndex.title: 50% Human & Brand - Where We Actually Win | 20-30-50 Framework
searchIndex.description: Master human connection and recruiter brand: plain-language messaging, trust-building conversations, and influence with hiring managers. AI drafts; you deliver with a human voice.
searchIndex.keywords: recruiter brand, human connection, trust building, outreach messaging, hiring manager influence, candidate engagement, recruiting communication
searchIndex.content: ü§ù 50% Human & Brand Where We Actually Win Candidates and hiring managers remember how you communicate, not which Boolean you used. GOAL The Objective Build trust with candidates and hiring managers by writing and speaking like a human. AI can draft the first version, but you own the voice and the relationship. üß© From 20% Role DNA = what to personalize around ü§ñ From 30% AI drafts options fast (you validate) ü§ù This 50% Tone, clarity, trust, influence, follow-through Keep it safe: follow AI Hiring Governance (no automated decisioning, protect candidate data, avoid bias). Simple ‚ÄúWrite-As-You-Speak‚Äù Frameworks Three simple rules you can use under pressure 1 Bar Test Rule: ‚ÄúWould I say this out loud in a coffee chat?‚Äù If not, it‚Äôs probably jargon. ‚úó Corporate speak ‚ÄúI‚Äôd love to present you with an exciting opportunity within a leading organization.‚Äù ‚úì Human speak ‚ÄúSaw your profile and thought you‚Äôre strong in X. Can I run a role past you?‚Äù Tiny reminder: ‚ÄúBar test: yes/no?‚Äù 2 3-Line Outreach SAY IT, THEN WRITE IT. Every cold message is 3 chunks (max): 1) Why you One true detail from their profile 2) Why this Role context + value (from Role DNA) 3) Next step One clear question (yes/no works) Example Why you: ‚ÄúNoticed you‚Äôve done ADC/bioconjugation work in Germany.‚Äù Why this: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre building X on a small team and you‚Äôd own Y.‚Äù Next step: ‚ÄúOpen to a 10-minute chat this week?‚Äù AI can help, but don‚Äôt outsource the human part Use AI to draft 3 versions, then run the Bar Test, remove fluff, and add one true detail you actually saw. 3 Jargon Swap (tiny word choices) If you use these words, candidates tune out: Instead of‚Ä¶ Say‚Ä¶ ‚Äúopportunity‚Äù ‚Äúrole‚Äù ‚Äúorganization‚Äù ‚Äúcompany‚Äù / ‚Äúteam‚Äù ‚Äúutilize‚Äù ‚Äúuse‚Äù ‚Äúproceed with your application‚Äù ‚Äúmove forward‚Äù / ‚Äúnext step‚Äù ‚Äúreach out‚Äù ‚Äúmessage‚Äù / ‚Äúwrite‚Äù Rule: If you wouldn‚Äôt say it out loud, pick the simpler word. BS FILTER Obvious Adams (the final quality check) Say the simple, honest, obvious thing AI gives you options. These frameworks give you structure. Obvious Adams makes sure you‚Äôre still saying something real. OPEN Open the full Obvious Adams framework The 5-Question Check Before you hit send, ask: 1) Obvious Problem What situation/pain is this person in right now? 2) Obvious Truth What honest thing proves you get it? 3) Obvious Fix What simple option are you offering? 4) Obvious Proof What concrete detail makes this believable? 5) Obvious Next Step What‚Äôs the smallest, clearest action you‚Äôre asking for? Rule of thumb If you can‚Äôt answer at least 3 out of 5 , you‚Äôre probably writing fluff. TRAINING Training Blocks Hands-on practice that ties 20% clarity + 30% drafting into 50% trust H1 Personalization in 2 Minutes (45 min) Objective: Use Role DNA + one true profile detail to write messages that feel real. Pick one live role and agree the Role DNA (from 20%). Pick one candidate profile and extract 1 true detail (project, tool, outcome). Draft a 3-line message (AI can draft variants; you choose and edit). Peer review with Bar Test + Obvious Adams (at least 3/5 answers). Outcome: A small ‚Äúhuman outreach‚Äù library you can reuse by function. H2 Voice & Tone Library (45 min) Objective: Create a consistent ‚Äúhuman voice‚Äù for your team (so AI drafts don‚Äôt sound generic). Collect 5 examples of messages you‚Äôd actually reply to (from the team). Extract: preferred length, tone, sign-off style, and ‚Äúbanned phrases‚Äù. Write a one-page ‚Äúvoice guide‚Äù (what we do / what we avoid). Outcome: Cleaner, more consistent outreach across the team. H3 Trust-Building Calls (60 min) Objective: Run calls that feel human: clear, honest, and candidate-centered. Practice a 3-part call: context ‚Üí role truth ‚Üí next steps. Use ‚ÄúObvious Proof‚Äù details (not hype): team size, manager style, scope, trade-offs. Close with one clear next step and timeframe. Outcome: Higher trust, fewer drop-offs, less ghosting. H4 HM Influence & Difficult Conversations (60 min) Use real examples: ‚Äúnot a culture fit‚Äù, ‚Äújust send more CVs‚Äù, slow feedback. Micro framework Write the corporate version first (how people usually write it). Run Bar Test + 3-Line Structure (acknowledge ‚Üí reality/risk ‚Üí next step). Run Obvious Adams (at least 3/5). Outcome: A ‚Äúplain language responses‚Äù playbook for tricky HM situations. This Is Where You Win Master these frameworks and you‚Äôll build trust, get responses, and create a brand people remember. searchIndex.content: üí° Obvious Adams Your BS Filter for Recruiting Say the obvious truth. Cut the corporate speak. Focus on what candidates and hiring managers actually care about. What Is Obvious Adams? Obvious Adams is your "BS filter" on top of all the other frameworks. AIDA, PAS, etc. tell you how to structure a message. Obvious Adams tells you: "Are we actually saying the obvious, true, useful thing the candidate/HM cares about or are we being clever and corporate again?" How Obvious Adams Fits Into 20-30-50 In the 203050 model, Obvious Adams mainly lives in the 50% Human & Brand part, but it also touches 20 and 30: 20% Search Craft Obvious roles, obvious talent pools first. Don't over-engineer "niche" until the basics are covered. 30% AI Assist Use AI to generate ideas, then apply Obvious Adams: "What is the simplest, most honest version of this?" 50% Human & Brand Every outreach, JD, LinkedIn post and HM email should pass the Obvious Adams test : Are we naming the obvious problem? Are we saying the obvious truth everyone feels but nobody writes? Are we offering the obvious next step? So it's less a "copy structure" and more a decision + clarity framework . The 5 Obvious Questions Ask yourself these before sending anything 1 Obvious Problem What is the most obvious pain this candidate/HM has right now? Example: "You're probably drowning in routine lab work with no time for your own research." 2 Obvious Truth What is the blunt, honest thing everyone knows but we rarely say? Example: "Let's be honest: this isn't a 9 to 5. But you get real ownership and a manager who actually backs you." 3 Obvious Fix What is the simple way this role/team actually improves that? Example: "This team gives you protected time for your own experiments, not just service work." 4 Obvious Proof What is one concrete fact / example that shows it's real, not marketing? Example: "The last scientist we hired published 2 papers in their first year from their own ideas, not assigned projects." 5 Obvious Next Step What's the smallest, clearest next step? Example: "Reply 'yes' or 'no', or I can send you 3 bullet points so you can decide in 30 seconds." Rule of Thumb: If your message doesn't hit at least 3 of these 5 , it's probably fluff. Outreach, Job ads, LinkedIn PAS Pain Twist Fix "Tired of 'send more CVs'? This team wants sourcers who push back." Outreach, Job ads, LinkedIn FAB Feature Why So-What "Modern lab = less waiting = more time for your experiments." Job ads, HM decks, Follow-up WIIFM What's In It For Me "Move from firefighting to focused work with manager who protects your time." EVERYWHERE 4U's Useful / Urgent / Unique / Specific "2-liner about a role where you design strategy, not follow it." Subject lines, Hooks HSO Hook Story Offer "Boolean means nothing if candidate experience is broken." LinkedIn posts, Branding PASTOR Problem Story Transform "TA leads stuck; one flipped it in 18 months; want the story?" Senior roles, Long posts Obvious Adams Say The Obvious Truth "Let's be honest: this isn't a 95, but you get real ownership of the portfolio and a manager who actually backs you in front of the business." Final edit/filter on all comms (Outreach, JDs, HM, LinkedIn) Concrete Before/After with Obvious Adams Scenario: Outreach to a senior scientist BEFORE (typical recruiter fluff): "I'd love to present you with an exciting opportunity at a leading global organization. We offer a competitive package and a dynamic environment." Run Obvious Adams: Obvious Problem? candidate is tired of vague promises, no clarity Obvious Truth? job will be demanding, but growth + ownership are real Obvious Fix? clearer scope, better manager, less chaos Obvious Proof? small team, real examples, not just buzzwords Obvious Next Step? small, easy: "can send 3 bullets / say no" AFTER (Obvious Adams version): "Let me be straight: this isn't a chill 95. You'd own a tough portfolio but you'd also get a manager who shields you from nonsense and actually backs your decisions. If you want, I can send 3 bullet points so you can decide in 30 seconds if it's worth a chat." Result: Same role, totally different trust signal. How to Use Obvious Adams 1 Write First Use any framework (AIDA, PAS, etc.) to write your message 2 Apply the Filter Run through the 5 Obvious Questions hit at least 3 3 Simplify & Send Cut corporate speak, say the obvious truth, make it human Key Principle: If you wouldn't say it to someone over coffee, don't write it in an email. searchIndex.content: ‚è≥ What AI Cannot Change The Timeless Truths of Great Recruiting In a world obsessed with the next AI tool, the best recruiters focus on what will never change. The Bezos Principle "I very frequently get the question: 'What's going to change in the next 10 years?' That is a very interesting question; it's a very common one. I almost never get the question: 'What's not going to change in the next 10 years?' " "And I submit to you that that second question is actually the more important of the two ‚Äî because you can build a business strategy around the things that are stable in time." ‚Äî Jeff Bezos For Amazon, it's low prices, fast delivery, and wide selection. For recruiting, it's trust , relationships , honesty , and the human element . These will never change. What Changes vs. What Stays üîÑ What Changes (Tools & Tech) ‚è≥ What Won't Change (Human Needs) Sourcing tools and platforms Candidates want to be treated with respect Automation of outreach People hire people they trust AI-generated messages Quality relationships compound over time Speed of screening Hiring managers want reliable, quality hires Data-driven decisions Candidates remember how you made them feel Boolean and search syntax Honesty and transparency always win The 8 Timeless Principles 1 Trust Is The Currency The Foundation of Every Hire Candidates and hiring managers remember how you made them feel long after they forget what tools you used. Trust is built in small moments: returning calls, being honest about timelines, following through on promises. Ask yourself: Would I trust myself if I were the candidate? 2 Speed + Quality, Not Just Speed Fast Is Meaningless Without Good AI makes everything faster. But fast garbage is still garbage. The best recruiters use speed to create more time for quality conversations, deeper assessments, and better matches ‚Äî not just more volume. Use AI speed to invest more time where it matters: human judgment. 3 Relationships Compound Today's Rejected Candidate Is Tomorrow's Hiring Manager Every interaction is an investment. The candidate you reject today may become a client in 3 years, or refer the perfect hire next month. Treat every person as a long-term relationship, not a transaction. Leave every interaction with someone who would recommend you. 4 Honesty Beats Spin "I Don't Know" Is Better Than Corporate Fluff Candidates can smell BS from a mile away. "I don't know, but I'll find out" builds more trust than polished corporate speak. Be direct about challenges, honest about timelines, and real about what the job actually involves. Apply the Obvious Adams test: Would a real person say this? 5 Respect Everyone's Time A Quick No Is Better Than Silent Maybe Time is the ultimate currency. Ghosting candidates, slow feedback, endless interview loops ‚Äî these destroy trust instantly. A respectful "no" in 24 hours is infinitely better than silence for 3 weeks. Set expectations early, update often, close the loop always. 6 Craft Never Dies Good Writing, Good Listening, Good Judgment AI can generate content, but craft is human. The ability to write a message that actually connects, to listen deeply in a conversation, to make judgment calls on cultural fit ‚Äî these skills become more valuable as AI handles the routine. Invest in the skills AI can't replicate: empathy, judgment, creativity. 7 Context Over Templates Understanding Beats Automation The best recruiters understand why a role matters, not just what it requires. They understand a candidate's career arc, not just their current title. Context enables personalization that no template can match. Before you automate, ask: Do I actually understand this? 8 Humans Hire Humans AI Assists, But The Decision Is Human At the end of every process, a human makes a decision about another human. AI can filter, score, suggest ‚Äî but the judgment about who joins a team, who fits a culture, who will thrive, remains fundamentally human. Use AI to get to the human conversation faster, not to replace it. üß™ The Timeless Test Before adopting any new AI tool, process, or approach, ask: "Will candidates and hiring managers still want this in 10 years?" ‚úì If YES Double down. Build systems around it. Train your team on it. ‚úó If NO It's a tactic, not a strategy. Use it, but don't depend on it. How This Connects These timeless principles are the foundation of everything we teach. They're embedded in our frameworks: ‚öñÔ∏è 20-30-50 Framework 50% Human & Brand exists because relationships and trust will always matter most. üí° Obvious Adams Honesty and clarity will always beat corporate speak and spin. ‚úçÔ∏è Copywriting Good writing is craft. Craft never dies. Focus on What Won't Change Tools will evolve. Platforms will rise and fall. But the fundamentals of human connection remain constant. Build your career on the timeless, and the technology will take care of itself. ‚Üê Back to Frameworks Hub Home

searchIndex.content: Session 1.1: Prompt Engineering 101 for Recruiters Your guide to moving from simple questions to expert commands. The #1 Skill for Working with AI The goal today is to become an expert instructor for your AI assistant. In our survey, the #1 skill gap was knowing how to get the AI to do what you actually want. Think of AI as the world's most brilliant junior assistant: it's incredibly fast and knowledgeable, but it has zero context about your job. A vague instruction gets a vague result. An expert instruction gets an expert result. A Tale of Two Prompts The "Before" Prompt This is how most people start. The result is generic, boring, and won't attract top talent because the AI has to guess everything. write a job description for a software engineer The "After" Prompt (C.R.E.A.T.E.) This is an expert command. It gives the AI a professional brief, not a vague question, leading to a high-quality result. [CHARACTER] You are an expert RPO recruiter and recruitment marketer... [REQUEST] Write a compelling job description for a "Senior Full-Stack Engineer" tailored to mid-market tech companies... [EXAMPLES] Provide 3 short example bullets showing desired tone (concise, action-oriented, benefits-focused). [ADDITIONS] Include location, required experience (5+ years), and must-have stacks (React, Node.js). [TYPE] Output: Sections ‚Äî Summary, Responsibilities, Required Skills, Nice-to-Have, Compensation Range, How to Apply. [EXTRAS] Tone: professional & persuasive; length: ~300 words; avoid buzzwords. The C.R.E.A.T.E. Framework An expert prompt contains six key ingredients. Mastering this structure is the key to getting high-quality results every time. Character Who should the AI be? Request What action should it perform? Examples What does a good output look like? Additions Extra context, constraints, or details Type Format / structure of the response Extras Tone, length, and items to avoid Lab Activities Lab 1: Creating a Candidate Persona (15 Mins) Your goal is to create a detailed candidate persona for a hard-to-fill "Senior Clinical Research Associate" role. If you don't know who you're looking for, you can't write content that resonates. Use the C.R.E.A.T.E. structure to build your prompt. View Example Persona Prompt [CHARACTER] You are a senior life sciences recruiter and candidate profiling expert... [REQUEST] Create a detailed candidate persona for a "Senior Clinical Research Associate" based in Budapest... [EXAMPLES] Provide sections and sample bullets (Summary, Demographics & Experience, Key Skills, Motivations, Where to Find Them). [ADDITIONS] Include typical certifications, seniority level, and travel expectations. [TYPE] Output: Headed sections with 3‚Äì5 bullets each. [EXTRAS] Tone: factual and recruiter-facing; keep concise. Lab 2: Drafting a Compelling Job Description (20 Mins) Now, use the persona you just created to draft a job description that speaks directly to them. This time, include Examples showing tone & structure in the prompt so the AI replicates it. View Example Job Description Prompt [CHARACTER] You are an expert recruitment marketing copywriter... [REQUEST] Write a full job description for a Senior CRA role targeting the persona we created... [EXAMPLES] Include a short sample opening paragraph that demonstrates the desired tone: "Join us in a role that advances clinical innovation..." [ADDITIONS] Include location, salary band (EUR mid-market), and required qualifications. [TYPE] Structure the output with headings: "Your Mission", "A Day in the Life", "Required Skills", "Benefits". [EXTRAS] Tone: confident & inclusive; length: ~350 words; avoid buzzwords like "rockstar". Wrap-Up & Next Steps Your new superpower is the C.R.E.A.T.E. Framework. Remember the golden rule: Vague Instructions = Vague Results. Expert Instructions = Expert Results. Optional Homework: Take a real role you're working on now. searchIndex.content: Session 2.1: AI for Advanced Sourcing Our Goal: To use AI to move beyond obvious keywords and become true market intelligence experts. We will find better candidates, faster. Part A: Boolean & Beyond Stop Brainstorming Keywords. Start Generating Them. The old way of writing a Boolean string is slow. You try to think of every possible synonym and job title. The new way is to tell the AI what you need and let it do the heavy lifting. The Evolution of a Search Prompt: Start with a simple idea: "Software Engineer with Python." Ask AI to expand it: "Give me a list of 20 alternative job titles and 30 related technical skills." Ask AI to build it: "Using these titles and skills, build me a complex Boolean search string for LinkedIn." View the "Boolean Builder" Prompt Example [ROLE] You are an expert tech sourcer with deep knowledge of LinkedIn Recruiter's search syntax. [CONTEXT] I am looking for a "Senior Software Engineer" with experience in Python, AWS, and database management. I need to create a comprehensive search string to find candidates in the Budapest area. [TASK] First, brainstorm a list of 15 alternative job titles and 20 related technical skills for this role. Then, using all of those terms, build me a complex, multi-layered Boolean search string that is optimized for LinkedIn Recruiter. [FORMAT] Provide the brainstormed lists first, then provide the final Boolean string in a code block. Part B: AI as Your Research Assistant Answer Questions in Minutes, Not Hours. Sourcing isn't just about finding people; it's about understanding the market. AI can be your personal research analyst. Here are three key research prompts: 1. Market Mapping "List the top 10 biotech companies specializing in gene therapy in the Boston area." 2. Competitor Analysis "Who are the main competitors for Company X, and what are their typical software engineering job titles?" 3. Rapid CV Analysis "Summarize this CV and create a table comparing the candidate's experience against these 5 key requirements from the job description." View the CV Summarization Prompt Example [ROLE] You are a senior RPO recruiter tasked with quickly screening candidates against a job description. [CONTEXT] I have a candidate's CV and the job description for the role they applied for. I need a fast, objective summary of how well they match the key requirements. [TASK] Read the CV and the Job Description provided below. Create a table with three columns: "Key Requirement," "Evidence from CV," and "Match Level (High/Medium/Low)." [FORMAT] The output should be ONLY the table. --- [PASTE JOB DESCRIPTION HERE] --- [PASTE CANDIDATE CV HERE] --- Lab Activities Lab 1: The Boolean Builder (20 Mins) Your Goal: Create a comprehensive Boolean string for a niche, hard-to-fill role like "Clinical Research Associate with Oncology experience." Work in your breakout groups. Use the prompt structure to build your own multi-layered prompt. Run the prompt in Gemini. Crucially: Test the resulting Boolean string in a real LinkedIn search! Lab 2: The 5-Minute Market Map (20 Mins) Your Goal: Quickly gather actionable intelligence on a specific market to inform your sourcing strategy. Choose a role and a city. Use research prompts to produce a one-page "Market Snapshot." Your snapshot must include: top 5 target companies, 3-5 common job titles, and a summary of one sample profile. Key Takeaways & Next Steps Your new superpower is letting AI do the heavy lifting on Search Logic, Market Research, and Candidate Analysis. The golden rule is to use AI to automate the research so you can spend more time on the human parts of recruiting: strategy and engagement. Next Session: Session 2.2 - The Randstad AI Toolkit: Gemini & Beyond. Next: Session 2.2

searchIndex.content: Session 2.2: The Randstad AI Toolkit Our Goal: To eliminate "tool confusion" with a simple decision-making framework that prioritizes security, integration, and efficiency. The Decision Framework A Simple 3-Step Process for Choosing the Right Tool 1 Check for Sensitive Data Is there ANY candidate, client, or internal data involved? If YES, you MUST use our secure, internal tool: Gemini. 2 Check for Integration Does the task need to connect with Docs, Gmail, or Sheets? If YES, Gemini for Google Workspace is the most efficient choice. 3 General Creative Tasks If you answered NO to the first two questions, a public tool like ChatGPT is an acceptable option for non-sensitive, creative brainstorming. Gemini's Strengths 1. Data Security (The #1 Priority) Everything we do stays within our secure Randstad Google environment. We are not sharing potentially sensitive client or job information with a public model. 2. Workflow Integration With one click, our work can be exported to Docs or drafted in Gmail. This is a huge efficiency gain. For 95% of our recruiting tasks, Gemini is the right choice. The Security Imperative: A Non-Negotiable Rule You must NEVER paste sensitive PII (Personally Identifiable Information) or Client Data into a public, non-approved AI tool. This includes names, emails, phone numbers, full CVs, client names, and project details. Doing so is a major data privacy and security risk. When in doubt, always default to our secure, internal platform. Lab Activity: "Choose Your Tool" Scenarios Scenario 1: You need to summarize your confidential interview notes about three candidates for a sensitive role with our top client. Which tool do you use? (Answer: Gemini) Scenario 2: You want to brainstorm some fun, catchy, generic slogans for a university career fair flyer. Which tool do you use? (Answer: Gemini) Scenario 3: You need to find a 30-minute slot for an interview with your candidate, two hiring managers, and one HR partner. Which tool do you use? (Answer: A specialized AI Scheduling Tool) Key Takeaways & Next Steps You now have a clear framework for choosing the right AI tool. The golden rule is Security First, Always. Use the right tool to work smarter, faster, and more securely. Next Session: Session 2.3 - Responsible AI in Recruiting & Final Showcase. Next: Session 2.3

searchIndex.content: Session 2.3: Responsible AI & Final Showcase Our Goal: To cover the most important topic of becoming responsible and ethical AI users, and then to celebrate your progress with a final showcase. What is AI Bias? AI models learn from vast amounts of internet data. The problem is that this data reflects the world as it has been, including all of its historical and unconscious biases. If we're not careful, the AI can simply echo and amplify these past biases. Our job is to be the filter that ensures fairness and equity. Where Can Bias Hide in Recruiting? In Job Descriptions Using gendered language (e.g., "rockstar," "ninja," "aggressive salesman"). Listing overly specific requirements that might exclude diverse talent pools (e.g., a degree from only one specific university). In CV Summaries Over-emphasizing traditional career paths and overlooking non-traditional experience. Unintentionally associating certain names with certain skills based on biased training data. Your critical eye is the most important tool. Lab Example: Fixing the Prompt In the lab, we practice identifying and correcting potentially biased AI outputs by rewriting the prompt that created them. The Biased AI Output: "We're looking for a digital native and recent graduate who is a true code ninja to join our young, energetic team." Potential Bias: Ageism ("recent graduate," "young"), gendered language ("ninja"), excludes experienced candidates. The Corrected, Inclusive Prompt: Write a job description for a software developer role. The ideal candidate should be proficient with modern coding practices and passionate about collaborative teamwork. The tone should be inclusive, professional, and welcoming to candidates of all ages and experience levels. The Most Important Principle You are the "Human in the Loop." AI is a powerful assistant, but it is not the decision-maker. You are the final editor, the final judge, and the final quality check. Your industry expertise and human judgment are what make this partnership work. Never Trust, Always Verify. Final Showcase: The Prompt-a-Thon! Time to celebrate your skills! Each team will present their single best prompt created during the training in a 2-3 minute pitch. We'll see the goal, the prompt, and the amazing result. After all presentations, we'll use a live poll to award the "People's Choice Award" for the most innovative and effective prompt! Phase 1 Complete & What's Next Congratulations! You have successfully completed the mandatory AI Foundations training. You are all now AI-enabled recruiters. The Journey Continues: For those who want to go deeper, consider the optional next phases: Phase 2: The AI Champions Track Phase 3: The AI for RPO Strategists Track Next: Session 3.1

You will learn how to make your data talk back to you, moving from being a user of data to becoming an analyst‚Äîall without writing a single complex formula. Core Skill 1: AI-Powered Data Cleaning Your New Data Janitor Forget manually fixing hundreds of rows. Use natural language to clean your entire dataset in seconds. Example 1: Standardizing Data The Mess: A column with "NY," "New York," and "nyc." Standardize the 'Location' column to the format 'City, State'. Example 2: Extracting Data The Mess: A "Notes" column filled with long sentences. Extract all mentioned technical skills from the 'Notes' column and place them in a new 'Skills' column. Core Skill 2: Generating Insights Become a Data Detective Once your data is clean, you can start asking it questions. 1. Asking Direct Questions "Which recruiter had the highest number of placements in Q2?" 2. Finding Trends "Show me the trend of time-to-fill over the last 6 months as a line chart." 3. Creating Visuals "Create a pie chart showing the distribution of candidates by source." Lab Activities Lab 1: The Data Janitor (20 Mins) Your Goal: Clean and structure a messy, real-world-style dataset using only natural language prompts. Open the sample Google Sheet provided. Use Gemini prompts to clean at least three different columns. Create one new column by extracting information from another. Be ready to share your most effective cleaning prompt! Lab 2: The Data Detective (20 Mins) Your Goal: To answer three specific business questions from your newly cleaned dataset using only natural language prompts. What is the average time-to-fill for roles in Texas vs. California? Who are the top 3 candidate sources that lead to hires? Create a bar chart showing the number of hires per month for the last 6 months. Key Takeaways & Next Steps Your new superpower is the ability to turn any spreadsheet into an interactive dashboard. The golden rule is that clean data is the foundation for good insights. Use AI to automate the cleaning so you can focus on the analysis. searchIndex.content: Session 3.2: Building an Intelligent Knowledge Base (No-Code RAG) Let's ask a question that was impossible yesterday: What if you could "talk" to your entire team's history of CVs and interview notes? Today, we're going to build the tool that does exactly that. What is RAG? (The Simple Explanation) It stands for Retrieval-Augmented Generation, and it sounds complicated, but the concept is simple. "RAG is the process of giving a brilliant expert (the AI) your private library of documents to read before they answer your question." This ensures the answers are grounded in your data, not the public internet. It's secure, relevant, and incredibly powerful. The Power of RAG: Meet Your "CV & Candidate Info Bot" This is what our final product will be able to do. Imagine asking a chat bot these questions about your team's private CV database: "Which candidates have experience with both Python and AWS?" "Summarize Jane Doe's experience and highlight her top 3 skills." "Who is the most experienced project manager for a fintech role based in London?" Today's Project: Build Your Bot This is a guided, hands-on lab. We will walk through every step together to create your first AI application. Part 1: The Build (20 Mins) We'll use a no-code tool (like Vertex AI Search) to create a secure "Data Store" and upload a provided set of 20-30 anonymized sample CVs. The system will then "read" and "index" this information. Part 2: The Test (40 Mins) Once indexing is complete, you'll get access to the chat interface for your bot. Your task is to complete the "Scavenger Hunt" to test its capabilities. Lab Task: The Scavenger Hunt Use the chat interface for the bot you just built to find the answers to these questions: Find all candidates with a PMP certification. Which candidates mention "data analysis" as a skill? Summarize the CV of the candidate named "John Smith". Who has more years of experience in management, "Jane Doe" or "Peter Jones"? Which candidate is the best fit for a role requiring experience in both marketing and e-commerce? Explain why. Key Takeaways & Next Steps Your new superpower is that you have just built one of the most powerful tools in modern AI: a secure application that can reason over your team's collective knowledge. The golden rule is that the power of RAG is its ability to ground AI in trusted, specific data. Next Module: Module 4 - Automating Recruiting Workflows. Next: Session 4.1

searchIndex.content: Session 4.1: Introduction to No-Code Automation Our Goal: To build a workflow that completely automates a boring task. Let's connect the dots and build a system that works for you, even when you're not looking. The "Finished Product" Demo See Where We're Going Imagine this hands-free workflow we are building today: An email with candidate feedback arrives in your Gmail and you give it a label. You do nothing else. A moment later, a new row appears in your tracking spreadsheet, automatically filled with the candidate's name, a one-sentence summary, and a sentiment score. How Does Automation Actually Work? APIs Think of an API as a waiter in a restaurant. It's how different apps talk to each other, taking requests and returning data. Triggers This is the "When this happens..." part of the equation. For us, it's "When a new email gets the label 'Candidate Feedback'..." Actions This is the "...Then do that" part. For us, it's "...run my script to analyze it and add it to the spreadsheet." Our Platform: Google Apps Script We will be using Google Apps Script. It's built into your Google account and is perfect for connecting Google products. It uses a simplified version of JavaScript. Don't worry! You do not need to be a coder. We will provide you with a well-commented code template. Your job is to understand the logic, not to write code from scratch. Lab Activity: The End-to-End Workflow (65 Mins) Your Goal: To build and test the full, automated workflow from email to spreadsheet. The Plan of Action: The Connection: Use the provided template to create a script and set up the trigger to read emails from Gmail. The AI: Add the Gemini API call to the script to analyze the email's content. The Destination: Add the final lines of code to populate your Google Sheet. The Test: Send a sample email to yourself, label it, and watch the magic happen! The "Magic" Prompt This is the key to making the workflow intelligent. This prompt forces the AI to give us back perfectly structured data that our spreadsheet can understand. From the following email text, extract the candidate's name, provide a one-sentence summary of the feedback, and classify the interviewer's sentiment as Positive, Negative, or Neutral. Return this as a JSON object. Key Takeaways & Next Steps Your new superpower is that you didn't just run a script; you built a system. The golden rule is to identify the most repetitive, copy-paste parts of your job, as these are the perfect candidates for automation. Next Module: Module 5 - Train the Trainer & Project Showcase. Next: Session 5.1

searchIndex.content: Session 5.1: Becoming an AI Champion Your journey so far has made you a skilled power user. This session is about the final, most important step: learning how to share that knowledge. You are now the AI leaders for your team. Your role is to empower, guide, and support. The Mentor Mindset Coach, Don't Just Tell The biggest shift you will make is from being the "expert with the answers" to becoming an "enabler of others' success." Telling "Here, let me just write the prompt for you." Result: Solves one problem, but doesn't build skill. Coaching "That's a great question. What have you tried so far?" Result: Builds your colleague's confidence and problem-solving ability. Your goal is to make yourself redundant. Teach them how to fish. The "Ask, Don't Tell" Model in Action Instead of giving the answer, use these guiding questions to help your colleagues find their own solution. "What's the ideal output you're looking for?" "What's the most important piece of context the AI might be missing?" "If you were to give the AI a role, what would it be?" "What have you tried so far, and what were the results?" How to Lead a Great Prompt Clinic When a colleague is stuck, use this simple 5-step framework to guide a group problem-solving session. 1. Set the Stage: Start by saying, "This is a no-judgment zone. Let's solve this together." 2. Understand the Goal: Let the person explain what they want to achieve. 3. Open the Floor: Ask the group, "What ideas does the team have?" 4. Guide, Don't Drive: Help the user refine their own prompt based on the group's feedback. 5. Summarize the Win: End with, "Great! The key change that worked here was adding more context." Lab Activities Lab 1: Mock Prompt Clinic (20 Mins) Your Goal: To practice facilitating a problem-solving session in a safe environment. Break out into small groups. Each person takes a turn leading a 10-minute mini-clinic. Focus on the process of facilitation, not just the technical answer. Lab 2: Brainstorming Responses (15 Mins) Your Goal: To collectively brainstorm effective and reassuring responses to common concerns like "I don't have time for this." Focus on benefits, starting small, and offering support. Example: "I felt that way too at first, but let me show you one trick that saved me 30 minutes yesterday." Key Takeaways & Next Steps Your new superpower is that you are now a coach and a facilitator. Your success is now measured by the success of those you help. Empower, guide, and support. The Final Step: Session 5.2 - The Capstone Project Showcase. This is your chance to present the amazing tools you built to leadership and demonstrate the real-world value of AI to the business. The objective is to demonstrate the tangible business value, ROI, and innovative potential of the tools our AI Champions have built. The Keys to a Successful Presentation How to Communicate Your Project's Value 1. Speak in Business Terms Translate features into benefits. Instead of "We built a RAG application," say "We built a tool that reduces time-to-find-past-candidates by 90%." 2. Demonstrate Clear ROI Articulate the return on investment through metrics like time saved, improved data quality, or enhanced sourcing capabilities. 3. Tell a Compelling Story Structure your presentation as a narrative: The Problem ‚Üí Our Journey ‚Üí The Solution ‚Üí The Future Impact. 4. Influence Leadership Make a clear and confident case for continued support and adoption of your project. The Presentation Structure (10 Mins Total) Your Blueprint for a Powerful Pitch The Problem (1 min): "What was the manual process or business challenge we were facing?" Our Solution (1 min): "We built an automated workflow / an intelligent knowledge base to solve this." Briefly explain what it is. Live Demo (3-4 mins): A live, crisp demonstration of the tool in action. Practice this! The Impact & ROI (1-2 mins): "This tool saves an estimated X hours per week," or "This allows us to answer questions that were previously impossible." Quantify the value. Q&A with Leadership (3 mins): Be prepared to answer questions about scalability, cost, and impact. [ ] Are you ready to showcase the incredible work you've done? Good luck, Champions. This is your moment to shine. "Graduation" & The Path Forward Congratulations, AI Champions! Official Recognition: You are the inaugural graduating class of AI Champions. Your dedication has paved the way for the future of AI in our organization. Your Ongoing Role: You are now the internal consultants, mentors, and leaders who will drive the adoption of these powerful new tools across the team. Our goal is to collaboratively build the strategic map that will guide our team's AI efforts for the next year, ensuring we invest in projects that deliver maximum business value. The Strategic Foundation Connecting Capabilities to Business Goals 1. Our Team's Proven Capabilities We'll review the successful projects from the Phase 2 "AI Champions" showcase (e.g., the CV Bot, automated workflows). These are the tools we know we can build. 2. Our Department's Business Objectives We'll review our key goals for the year (e.g., reduce time-to-fill by 15%, improve source-of-hire quality, etc.). The Key Question for Today: "How can we apply our proven AI capabilities to directly accelerate our most important business objectives?" Workshop Part 1: Opportunity Mapping Brainstorming Across the Recruiting Lifecycle The Goal: To create a comprehensive list of all potential AI projects. The Activity: Using a digital whiteboard, we will map out the entire RPO lifecycle: Intake ‚Üí Sourcing ‚Üí Screening ‚Üí Submitting ‚Üí Scheduling ‚Üí Onboarding For each stage, we will brainstorm answers to two questions: What are our biggest pain points or bottlenecks in this stage? How could an AI tool or automation help solve them? The Prioritization Tool: The Impact vs. Effort Matrix Not all ideas are created equal. We will use this simple but powerful matrix to prioritize our list and spark crucial strategic conversations about value versus resources. Quick Wins (High Impact / Low Effort) Do these now! Major Projects (High Impact / High Effort) Plan for these. Fill-ins (Low Impact / Low Effort) Consider these later. Thankless Tasks (Low Impact / High Effort) Avoid these. From a Map to a Plan Workshop Part 2: Prioritizing The Goal: To create a prioritized visual map of all brainstormed ideas. As a leadership team, we will collectively discuss each idea from the Opportunity Mapping exercise and place it onto the Impact/Effort matrix. Workshop Part 3: Building the Roadmap The Goal: To select our top projects and create a clear, sequenced plan of action. We will identify the top 3-5 initiatives from the "Quick Wins" and "Major Projects" quadrants and sequence them on a simple timeline (e.g., Q3, Q4, Next Q1). Key Takeaways & Next Steps What We've Achieved Today: A shared vision for AI in our department. A comprehensive list of potential opportunities. A prioritized list of our top 3-5 projects. A draft roadmap for the next 6-9 months. This is our strategic foundation. Next Session: Session 7.1 - The ROI of AI in Recruiting. We will focus on defining how we will measure the success and calculate the ROI for these specific projects. Next: Session 7.1

searchIndex.content: Session 7.1: The ROI of AI in Recruiting A Strategic Workshop for RPO Leadership. Our goal is to build a data-driven, compelling business case for our top-priority project, turning our strategic ideas into funded, measurable projects. Defining Success What Does "Good" Look Like? Moving Beyond Anecdotes Leading Indicators These are the early signals of progress that show we're on the right track. Recruiter time saved per week Number of qualified candidates sourced via an AI tool Lagging Indicators These are the long-term business impact metrics that prove the value of our work. Reduction in average time-to-fill Improvement in 6-month new-hire retention We need a mix of both to tell the full story of our success. Calculating ROI: The Two Sides of Value Hard ROI: The Financial Case This is the quantifiable, bottom-line impact. It's the number that gets budgets approved. Formula: (Time Saved) x (# of People) x (Avg. Salary) = $$$ Saved Soft ROI: The Strategic Case This is the harder-to-measure but equally important strategic value that drives long-term success. Improved candidate quality Higher hiring manager satisfaction Enhanced team morale & retention The Simple Math of Hard ROI A Conservative Calculation Example The Project: Automating the summarization of interview feedback. The Assumption: This saves each of our 20 recruiters an average of 2 hours per week. The Calculation: 20 recruiters x 2 hours/week = 40 hours saved per week. 40 hours/week x 50 weeks/year = 2,000 hours saved per year. 2,000 hours x [Average Recruiter Hourly Rate] = $X in annual productivity gain. This is a powerful, conservative number to anchor your business case. Workshop Activities Part 1: KPI Mapping (30 Mins) Select your #1 project from the roadmap and answer: "If this project is a massive success one year from now, what 3-4 numbers on our dashboard will have changed?" Define at least two "hard" and one "soft" metric. Part 2: Building the Business Case (30 Mins) Draft a concise, one-page business case for your chosen project using the provided template. The template will include: Problem Statement, Proposed AI Solution, Key Metrics (KPIs), Estimated ROI, and Required Resources. Part 3: Peer Review & Final Refinement (15 Mins) In pairs, present your one-page business cases to each other. Your partner's job is to act as a skeptical leader: ask tough questions, point out weaknesses, and help you strengthen your argument. From Vision to Action Plan After today, you will have a clear set of KPIs, a defensible method for calculating ROI, and a drafted, peer-reviewed business case for your top priority. You are now fully prepared to present your vision to GBS leadership. The Final Step: The Capstone Presentation. You will now formalize these plans into a final presentation to secure the resources needed to make our AI strategy a reality. Back to RPO Training
